item.title: Duhem-Quine thesis
item.description: Named after Pierre Duhem and Quine: It is impossible to test a scientific hypothesis in isolation, because an empirical test of the hypothesis requires one or more background assumptions.

item.title: Epistemological skepticism
item.description: There are many flavors of this form of skepticism, but consider the brain in a vat thought experiment: You are sleeping one night, when the scientist takes out your brain, puts it in a vat, and connects its neurons to a machine that gives/receives electrical inputs such that the brain activity is identical to certain possible real life scenarios if the brain was still in the body.

item.title: Hesperus and Phosphorus
item.description: From Wikipedia These are puzzles posed by Frege. They are addressed by making a distinction between sense and reference. First puzzle The brightest star in morning was called Hesperus, and the brightest star of evening was called Phosphorus.

item.title: Indexicals
item.description: A grammatical construct in natural languages which is explicitly context-sensitive. Examples: pronouns, such as “I” and “he” “here” “today” These are an important case for any general semantic theory to address.

item.description: A dualism. Descartes had invented representation but came to think of things things in the world to be divided into representeds (things) and representings (ideas).

item.title: Modality
item.description: According to the Kant-Sellars thesis, the distinctive expressive job of modal vocabulary is to articulate the inferential connections among descriptive concepts in virtue of which they have the content that they do.

item.title: Myth of the Museum

item.title: Normative character of representation
item.description: To count as representing something is to be responsible to the represented thing What is represented provides the normative standard for correctness of representing.

item.title: Nothing-but-ism
item.description: Sellars’ term for the consequence of descriptivism (the tendency to assimlate all discourse to describing). Examples: Emotivism claims about what you ought to do are not saying anything about how the world is Behaviorism what we should be doing is describing the behavior, not looking upstream towards the internal representations Phenomenalism physical objects are nothing but logical constructions out of sensory experiences

item.title: Object naturalism and subjective naturalism
item.description: A distinction about naturalism made by Huw Price. Priority thesis Huw argues that object naturalists must accept subject naturalists, but not vice-versa.

item.title: Philosophy of language
item.description: A subdiscipline of philosophy. Two traditions Logistical tradition Runs from Frege/ Russell, through the Tractatus, Carnap, Tarski, Quine, David Lewis Operative paradigm: formal calculi suitable for proofs about artificial symbolic languages tarskian model theory as a paradigm of semantics more powerful successor: possible worlds semantics Anthropological tradition Focuses on natural languages over artificial ones Thinks of languages as a social practice characteristic of biological creatures like us Dewey, early Heidegger, late Wittgenstein, Rorty.

item.title: Reference
item.description: Grammar Grammatically, one signals reference with of. E.g.: I’m thinking of a number As a relation Reference has been thought of as a relation between linguistic terms and things in the world.

item.title: Representation
item.description: Representation is a theory of the relation between appearance and reality. A successor concept to theories of resemblance Premodern theories understood relation between appearance and reality in terms of resemblance (sharing properties).

item.title: Rigid designator
item.description: Saul Kripke’s theory of the meaning of names (from Naming and Necessity) that is alternative to descriptivism: A name refers to the same object in all possible worlds in which that object exists, and the name never refers to anything else.

item.title: Semantic skepticism
item.description: A Kantian insight: the real problematic skepticism is semantic skepticism. He doesn’t take it for granted that we can ‘represent’ reality and merely have to worry about whether or not that representation is true.

item.title: Semantics
item.description: Empiricism An empiricist approach to semantics wants to give semantics of an expression in terms of its sense dependence rather than its reference dependence.

item.title: Successor concept
item.description: A relationship between concepts across vocabularies. The successor concept does the work the old concept did, yet it is improved in some way.

item.title: Teleosemantics
item.description: Developed by Ruth Millikan. A simple example: imagine that beavers slap their tail when there’s danger, and beavers flee when they hear another beaver slap its tail.

item.title: The Frege-Geach problem
item.description: A problem for people who subscribe to emotivism. Sets a critirion of adequacy for them. Also sometimes called the embedding problem.

item.title: Universals
item.description: It seems there is no problem thinking about what triangles and white things are, but what of triangularity and whiteness?
